Drug-Induced Liver Injury.title: Hepatotoxicity Assessment of Novel Therapeutics Using Advanced 3D Hepatic Models

authors.name: Dr. Sarah Chen
authors.affiliation: Toxicology Research Center, Boston Medical College

Drug-Induced Liver Injury.abstract: This study evaluates hepatotoxicity using advanced 3D hepatic cell models for early-stage drug screening. We present a novel framework for predicting drug-induced liver injury (DILI) in preclinical development, utilizing engineered tissue models that better recapitulate in vivo hepatic responses. Our methodology demonstrates 95% accuracy in identifying hepatotoxic compounds compared to traditional 2D models, offering a paradigm shift in safety assessment protocols.

Drug-Induced Liver Injury.title: Multi-Omics Integration for Hepatic Safety Prediction
Drug-Induced Liver Injury.abstract: We present a comprehensive multi-omics approach to identify biomarkers predictive of drug-induced hepatotoxicity. By integrating genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data from human hepatocytes exposed to known hepatotoxins, we identified novel signatures of DILI risk. This work facilitates early identification of unsafe compounds and supports de-risking of drug development programs.

Drug-Induced Liver Injury.title: Regulatory Framework for DILI Risk Assessment in Drug Development
Drug-Induced Liver Injury.abstract: Drug-induced liver injury remains a leading cause of drug attrition and post-marketing withdrawals. This paper reviews current regulatory expectations for hepatic safety assessment and proposes a tiered approach for DILI risk characterization using a combination of in vitro and in vivo methods.

3D cell culture.title: Engineered Tissues for Disease Modeling: Advances in 3D Culture Systems
3D cell culture.abstract: Recent advances in 3D culture technologies have revolutionized disease modeling and drug screening. This review synthesizes current approaches in scaffold-free and scaffold-based 3D culture systems, highlighting their applications in personalized medicine and therapeutic development. Our analysis shows superior cellular behavior recapitulation in 3D compared to traditional monolayer cultures.

3D cell culture.title: Biomaterial Selection for Optimized 3D Cellular Microenvironments

authors.name: Prof. Hans Mueller
authors.affiliation: Biomedical Engineering Department, Swiss Institute of Technology

authors.name: Dr. Sophia Rossi
authors.affiliation: Biomedical Engineering Department, Swiss Institute of Technology

3D cell culture.abstract: The selection of appropriate biomaterials is critical for creating 3D cell culture systems that accurately model physiological conditions. We evaluated 12 distinct biomaterial platforms for their capacity to support long-term culture while maintaining cellular functionality and gene expression patterns comparable to in vivo tissues.

3D cell culture.title: High-Throughput Screening in 3D: Scaling Culture Systems for Drug Discovery

authors.name: Dr. Carlos Gonzalez
authors.affiliation: Drug Discovery Platform, Bay Area Biotech

3D cell culture.abstract: Scaling 3D culture systems for high-throughput drug screening presents significant technical challenges. We describe an automated platform for maintaining and assaying 384-well plates of spheroid cultures, enabling rapid evaluation of thousands of compounds with improved predictivity compared to 2D screening approaches.

Toxicology.title: Integrative Toxicology Assessment Using Alternative Methods
Toxicology.abstract: This paper presents an integrated framework for toxicological assessment combining multiple alternative methods including genomics, proteomics, and 3D cellular models. The approach reduces reliance on animal testing while maintaining robust predictivity for human health hazards.

Toxicology.title: Mechanistic Toxicology: Systems-Based Approach to Safety
Toxicology.abstract: Understanding the mechanisms of toxicity is essential for predicting and preventing adverse effects. We propose a systems-based approach that integrates toxicodynamics with pharmacokinetics to predict safety margins across diverse molecular targets and tissues.

Toxicology.title: Computational Toxicology for Pharmaceutical Development
Toxicology.abstract: Computational methods enable rapid screening of chemical libraries for potential toxicity liabilities early in drug development. Our machine learning models, trained on comprehensive toxicological datasets, achieve 92% accuracy in predicting hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and off-target effects.
